item.title: An introduction to Node.js
item.description: Node.js is an extremely high performance server-side JavaScript framework. It solves the same problems as server-side tools such as PHP, Django or Ruby on Rails, using JavaScript as the programming language and with a focus on non-blocking, highly concurrent event-based programming.

image.title: look downstairs into stairwell whirl by quapan, on Flickr

item.title: First Birthday Show n' Tell
item.description: Happy Birthday to us! Happy Birthday to us!

image.title: Happy Beaver by stevehdc, on Flickr

item.title: Micro Frameworks
item.description: Micro frameworks have always existed as small scripts (say, less than 5kb of code) for handling very specific tasks, from templating to inheritance to animation. With the common JavaScript frameworks increasing in size with every release, people have begun to question whether all that code is necessary for your average site. Perhaps it‚Äôs possible to get away with a few small scripts that handle the majority of use cases.

item.title: Building browser-based web apps, with Backbone.js
item.description: This week's Async, with Aron Carroll and Premasagar Rose, is about creating browser-based web applications, using the "MVC" library Backbone.js.

item.title: Everything Express
item.description: Alex Young (writer and editor of DailyJS.com) presents this session on building web apps with the server-side JavaScript framework, Node.js, and the web framework, Express.

image.title: The Railroad Depot by Stuck in Customs, on Flickr

item.title: Show Us Your Privates (er, JavaScript Design Patterns)
item.description: JavaScript is a richly diverse language with a million and one approaches to solving a problem. Its flexibility can be both a blessing and a curse, but through the myriad of choices, interesting coding patterns start to emerge.

image.title: Wind cube by Andrei Z, on Flickr

item.title: 3D JS
item.description: You can now render 3D in JavaScript in the browser. Seb Lee-Delisle will show you how to get started with the powerful and complex engine Three.js, made by Mr.Doob and his team.

item.title: Patterns for Performance
item.description: There are many challenges to developing a streamlined JavaScript application and, depending on the type of app being created, there may be bottlenecks to its performance. It is important to understand which kinds of bottleneck can apply in any given situation and focus time on addressing them, instead of less critical issues.

image.title: vintage clockwork macro by Sergei Golyshev, on Flickr

item.title: Chrome Extensions & the Chrome Web Store
item.description: The Google Chrome browser now has over 120 million active users. Developers can reach those users via Chrome's facilities for browser extensions and installable web apps, which are the subject of this Async session by Google's own Michael Mahemoff.

item.description: We are extremely chuffed and humbled to have been given a sponsorship by The Guardian, one of the most widely news sites on the Web. The newspaper is unique in being not-for-profit, at the forefront of global data journalism and by supporting developer partnerships via its innovative Open Platform service for embedded applications.

item.title: I Can't Believe It's Not Flash
item.description: For the last ten years, Flash developers have been creating rich media apps and games with immersive visuals. Now that the open standards Canvas and SVG are available natively in all major browsers, we JavaScript developers have much to learn from the techniques that Flash devs have put to use this past decade.

item.title: Modular JavaScript with RequireJS
item.description: In this session, Kyran Dale gives a practical introduction to RequireJS, an open-source library for creating modular JavaScript applications. With RequireJS, code can be organised into separate modules that can be loaded asynchronously in the browser, without polluting the global namespace.

item.description: Async has hosted JavaScript Show n' Tells before (one here and one there), but this one's a little special, because this time there'll be a boatload of international visitors in Brighton for the legendary Full Frontal conference.
